thread.section_title: Woman claims London terror attacker was her next door neighbour – Metro
thread.title: Woman claims London terror attacker was her next door neighbour
thread.title_full: Woman claims London terror attacker was her next door neighbour

author: georgiadiebelius1
title: Woman claims London terror attacker was her next door neighbour
text:
Police are carrying out a forensic search in a property at the Quayside (Picture: SWNS) A woman has claimed that the man behind yesterday’s terror attack in London is her former next door neighbour.
Iwona Romek , 45, from Birmingham, said that she believed she used to say ‘hello’ to the man behind the incident, which killed four people.
London attacker named as Khalid Masood However, she was unable to provide his name.
The Islamic State terror group, ISIS, claimed responsibility for the attack through its news agency this afternoon.
They claim that the attacker, who has been named by police as Khalid Masood , was a ‘soldier of the Islamic State’.
Islamic State has claimed it was behind the Westminster attack (Picture: SWNS) Theresa May has told Parliament that the perpetrator was a British citizen (Picture: SWNS) Mrs Romek said that she recognised the man ‘straight away’ – and that he moved out of the house with a woman and a small child in December.
She said: ‘When I saw the pictures on TV and in the papers of the man who carried out the attack, I recognised him as the man who used to live next door.
No, Fox News, London did not 'shut down' after the terror attack on Parliament ‘I would see him quite often, but it would just be a “hello” and a “how are you”.
‘He had a young child, who I’d think was about five or six years old.
‘There was a woman living there with him, an Asian woman.
‘He seemed to be quite nice, he would be taking care of his garden and the weeds.
‘He moved out in December, very soon. One day he was gone, there were delivery vans outside all of a sudden.’
He was known to police and security services (Picture: SWNS) Emergency services at the scene outside the Palace of Westminster (Picture: Stefan Rousseau/PA Wire) What happened outside Parliament Members of the emergency services work to help vicitms on Westminster Bridge, alongside the Houses of Parliament in central London on March 22, 2017, during an emergency incident (Picture: Getty) A massive police investigation is under way after a terror attack in central London.
Here’s everything we know so far about the Westminster attack: 
Four people have died – a police officer, the attacker, a woman named as Aysha Frade, 43, and a man in his mid 50s.
The officer was Pc Keith Palmer, a 48-year-old husband and father with 15 years of police service.
A minute’s silence was held at 9.33am to honour Palmer, whose police shoulder number was 933. 
Eight people have been arrested and six addresses raided across London, Birmingham and elsewhere. 
The woman was killed on Westminster Bridge as a number of pedestrians were mowed down by a grey Hyundai i40.
It is believed the man was also killed in the incident on the bridge.
Seven people are in a critical condition, and 29 have been treated in hospital.
One woman ended up in the Thames and was treated for serious injuries after being pulled from the water.
The attacker, armed with two large knives, jumped out of the car after smashing it into the railings encircling the Palace of Westminster, fatally stabbing Pc Palmer as he entered the grounds.
He was shot dead moments later by another officer.
During a speech in Parliament, Theresa May confirmed the Westminster attacker was a British citizen who was known to the police and security services, and had been investigated some years ago over violent extremism.
May told MPs he was a ‘peripheral’ figure, adding: ‘He was not part of the current intelligence picture.’
Here’s everything we know about the attacker.
Defence Secretary Michael Fallon has said the working assumption is that the attack is linked to Islamic terrorism.
A group of French schoolchildren were among those targeted on the bridge, with three injured.
Prime Minister Theresa May later chaired a meeting of the Government’s emergency Cobra committee, branding the attack ‘sick and depraved’.
To see all of our coverage of the London terror attack click here. 
 
Last night, eight people were arrested in connection with the terror attack.
Police raided six addresses in London and Birmingham – including the home next door to Mrs Romek, she claims.
Kate Middleton reaches out to victims affected by London terror attack She said: ‘Last night I just heard banging of the door and police shouting “open the door, open the door”.
‘They were saying “it’s on the second floor”. I heard the helicopters flying above too.
‘Men were going in in the forensics outfits, it was very strange.
‘I’m shaking and I’m nervous. I don’t know if I can live here anymore, I’ve been here for 12 years.
‘I just thought they were a normal family.’
